segments.text: Early next morning at breakfast, Dorian sits quietly when Basil Hallward is shown into the room. The atmosphere is heavy with unspoken worry and regret.

voice_traits.pauses: slight pauses at natural breaks
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: narrative clarity with understated gravity

segments.text: I am so glad I have found you, Dorian. I called last night, and they told me you were at the opera. Of course, I knew that was impossible. But I wish you had left word where you had really gone to. I passed a dreadful evening, half afraid that one tragedy might be followed by another. I think you might have telegraphed for me when you heard of it first. I read of it quite by chance in a late edition of The Globe that I picked up at the club. I came here at once and was miserable at not finding you. I can’t tell you how heart-broken I am about the whole thing. I know what you must suffer. But where were you? Did you go down and see the girl’s mother? For a moment I thought of following you there. They gave the address in the paper. Somewhere in the Euston Road, isn’t it? But I was afraid of intruding upon a sorrow that I could not lighten. Poor woman! What a state she must be in! And her only child, too! What did she say about it all?

voice_traits.tone: somber, heavy with regret and concern
voice_traits.pacing: slow and deliberate with sincere pauses
voice_traits.pauses: pausing thoughtfully between questions
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: slightly formal diction with an undercurrent of artistic melancholy

segments.text: My dear Basil, how do I know? I was at the opera. You should have come on there. I met Lady Gwendolen, Harry’s sister, for the first time. We were in her box. She is perfectly charming; and Patti sang divinely. Don’t talk about horrid subjects. If one doesn’t talk about a thing, it has never happened. It is simply expression, as Harry says, that gives reality to things. I may mention that she was not the woman’s only child. There is a son, a charming fellow, I believe. But he is not on the stage. He is a sailor, or something. And now, tell me about yourself and what you are painting.
segments.emotion: bored yet dismissive, with a hint of amusement

segments.text: You went to the opera? You went to the opera while Sibyl Vane was lying dead in some sordid lodging? You can talk to me of other women being charming, and of Patti singing divinely, before the girl you loved has even the quiet of a grave to sleep in? Why, man, there are horrors in store for that little white body of hers!

segments.text: Stop, Basil! I won’t hear it!

segments.text: What has the actual lapse of time got to do with it? It is only shallow people who require years to get rid of an emotion. A man who is master of himself can end a sorrow as easily as he can invent a pleasure. I don’t want to be at the mercy of my emotions. I want to use them, to enjoy them, and to dominate them.

segments.text: Dorian, this is horrible! Something has changed you completely. You look exactly the same wonderful boy who, day after day, used to come down to my studio to sit for his picture. But you were simple, natural, and affectionate then. You were the most unspoiled creature in the whole world. Now, I don’t know what has come over you. You talk as if you had no heart, no pity in you. It is all Harry’s influence. I see that.

voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: sincere, with lingering intonation on key phrases

segments.text: I owe a great deal to Harry, Basil, more than I owe to you. You only taught me to be vain.

segments.text: Only my Christian name, and that I am quite sure she never mentioned to anyone. She told me once that they were all rather curious to learn who I was, and that she invariably told them my name was Prince Charming. It was pretty of her. You must do me a drawing of Sibyl, Basil. I should like to have something more of her than the memory of a few kisses and some broken pathetic words.

segments.text: A cry of terror breaks from Dorian’s lips as he rushes between the painter and the screen, his face drained of color. The tension in the room mounts as secrets of the portrait and of their friendship hang in the balance.

segments.text: If you try to look at it, Basil, on my word of honour I will never speak to you again as long as I live. I am quite serious. I don’t offer any explanation, and you are not to ask for any. But, remember, if you touch this screen, everything is over between us.

segments.text: But what is the matter? Of course I won’t look at it if you don’t want me to, but really, it seems rather absurd that I shouldn’t see my own work—especially as I am going to exhibit it in Paris in the autumn. I shall probably have to give it another coat of varnish before that, so I must see it some day, and why not to-day?
segments.emotion: calm yet insistent, with a note of incredulity

segments.text: Yes; I don’t suppose you will object to that. Georges Petit is going to collect all my best pictures for a special exhibition in the Rue de Sèze, which will open the first week in October. The portrait will only be away a month. I should think you could easily spare it for that time. In fact, you are sure to be out of town. And if you keep it always behind a screen, you can’t care much about it.

voice_traits.emotion: neutral, with a focus on practicality
voice_traits.pauses: evenly spaced to separate the factual details
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: formal and explanatory, as if reading a set of instructions

segments.text: You told me a month ago that you would never exhibit it. Why have you changed your mind? You people who go in for being consistent have just as many moods as others have. The only difference is that your moods are rather meaningless. You can’t have forgotten that you assured me most solemnly that nothing in the world would induce you to send it to any exhibition. You told Harry exactly the same thing.

voice_traits.pauses: intersperse short pauses for emphasis on contradictions
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: delivers a tirade in a measured yet rising tone of indignation

segments.text: Basil, we have each of us a secret. Let me know yours, and I shall tell you mine. What was your reason for refusing to exhibit my picture?

voice_traits.pauses: well-timed to build suspense

segments.text: Dorian, if I told you, you might like me less than you do, and you would certainly laugh at me. I could not bear your doing either of those two things. If you wish me never to look at your picture again, I am content. I have always had you to look at. If you wish the best work I have ever done to be hidden from the world, I am satisfied. Your friendship is dearer to me than any fame or reputation.

voice_traits.emotion: deep vulnerability and a tender sadness
voice_traits.pauses: strategically long to emphasize his inner conflict
voice_traits.distinctive_speech_patterns: confessing in a hushed, sincere manner that borders on despair

segments.text: No, Basil, you must tell me. I think I have a right to know.

segments.text: Let us sit down, Dorian. And just answer me one question. Have you noticed in the picture something curious—something that probably at first did not strike you, but that revealed itself to you suddenly? From the moment I met you, your personality had the most extraordinary influence over me. I was dominated—soul, brain, and power—by you. You became to me the visible incarnation of that unseen ideal whose memory haunts us artists like an exquisite dream. I worshipped you. I grew jealous of every one to whom you spoke. I wanted to have you all to myself. I was only happy when I was with you. When you were away from me, you were still present in my art.... I have tried to capture your perfection in myth and allegory—a Paris in dainty armour, an Adonis with a huntsman’s cloak, even as you sat crowned with lotus-blossoms upon a barge drifting on the green Nile. But one day, a fatal day I sometimes think, I resolved to paint you as you truly are, not in costume of dead ages, but in your own dress and time. As I worked on it, every shade of colour revealed my secret. I became afraid; I felt I had bet too much of myself on your beauty. I resolved never to allow the picture to be exhibited. I told Harry as much. Once, Dorian, you are made to be worshipped—yet I see now that the picture cannot be shown.
segments.emotion: confessional, trembling with vulnerability and artistry

segments.text: As Basil leaves the room, Dorian smiles to himself. A quiet, secret satisfaction mingles with a pit of pity: poor Basil, so beguiled by his own intense adoration, remains unaware of the true reason behind Dorian’s anxiety. Dorian contemplates the dangerous power of the portrait and the tragic, romantic nature of their friendship, resolved that the portrait must be hidden away forever to protect his secret.
